answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found a number of areas moving to change how they display legal ads. 
In Georgia they have established a public notice website in addition to newspaper releases to help bring them altogether in one place.
http://georgiapublicnotice.com/
I found a similar site for the state of Louisiana which you can view below.
http://www.publicnoticeads.com/la/
I have also included a list of places currently working to end newspaper ads. You may want to contact each area for more information on the challenges they have been facing.
Jefferson City, Missouri:
http://www.columbiamissourian.com/stories/2010/02/08/legislators-press-discuss-government-postings/
Harrisburg, Pennsylvania: 
http://articles.philly.com/2011-05-20/news/29564388_1_legal-notices-newspapers-legal-ads
Augusta, Maine:
http://bangordailynews.com/2011/05/03/business/bill-would-cut-legal-ads-from-newspapers/
Chattanooga, Tennessee:
http://chattarati.com/metro/government-politics/2011/3/1/move-legal-notices-web-council-says/
Trenton, New Jersey:
http://www.wnyc.org/blogs/wnyc-news-blog/2011/feb/06/nj-newspapers-fight-save-legal-notices/
I have also included a report from Binghamton University entitled, The Potential Impacts of a Competitive Environment for Local Government Legal Notices. It discusses the changing market of newspapers in relation to public notices.
http://www2.binghamton.edu/clg/potential-impacts.pdf
I hope these are helpful!
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Mark Abeles-Allison
text:
Legal ads are a significant expense for our county.  Required publications for delinquent taxes, minutes, etc add up. 
Does anyone print condensed minutes with web links to the complete minutes?  Do any communities do anything unique with smaller fonts.  Are  there legal opinions allowing for newspaper ads with web links that meet statutory requirements?
Thank you.
title: Saving Dollars with Legal Ads?
